# Overview

The `mestools` package provides a comprehensive collection of utility functions for data analysis, package development, and bioinformatics workflows. This vignette introduces the main features and demonstrates common use cases.

## Installation

```{r installation}
# Install from GitHub
# devtools::install_github("vanhungtran/mestools")

# Load the package
library(mestools)
```

## Main Features

### 1. Package Development Tools

The package includes tools to streamline R package development and deployment:

```{r package-dev}
# Validate a GitHub repository
validate_github_repo("https://github.com/r-lib/usethis.git")

# Deploy package to GitHub (automated workflow)
deploy_package(
  package_name = "mypackage",
  repo_url = "https://github.com/username/mypackage.git",
  run_tests = TRUE,
  run_check = TRUE
)
```

### 2. Utility Functions

#### Check and Install Dependencies

```{r dependencies}
# Check if required packages are available
required_pkgs <- c("dplyr", "ggplot2", "tidyr")
check_dependencies(required_pkgs)

# Install and load packages automatically
install_and_load(c("dplyr", "ggplot2"))
```

#### Create Project Structure

```{r project-structure}
# Create a standardized project directory structure
dirs <- c("data", "scripts", "results", "figures")
create_project_structure(dirs, base_path = "my_project")
```

#### Generate Random Data

```{r random-data}
# Generate random data frame for testing
df <- generate_random_df(nrows = 100, ncols = 5)
head(df)
```

### 3. Data Processing

#### Batch Apply Functions

Apply functions to lists or vectors with error handling:

```{r batch-apply}
# Process multiple files with error handling
files <- c("file1.csv", "file2.csv", "file3.csv")
results <- batch_apply(files, read.csv, show_progress = TRUE)
```

#### Safe File Reading

```{r safe-reading}
# Read files with automatic error handling
data <- read_file_safe("myfile.csv", type = "csv")
```

### 4. Data Summaries

```{r summary}
# Quick summary of data objects
df <- data.frame(x = rnorm(100), y = runif(100))
quick_summary(df)
```

## GEO Dataset Functions

The package includes specialized functions for working with GEO datasets:

```{r geo-data}
# Read a single GEO dataset
geo_data <- read_geo_dataset("GSE102628")

# Read multiple GEO datasets
gse_list <- get_default_gse_list()
results <- read_multiple_geo_datasets(gse_list[1:3])
```

## 16S Primer Analysis

See the dedicated vignette for comprehensive 16S primer analysis tools:

```{r primer-tools}
# Get available primers
primers <- get_16s_primers()
head(primers)

# Search for specific primers
v4_primers <- search_16s_primers(region = "V4")

# Get primer statistics
stats <- get_primer_stats(primers)
print_primer_stats(stats)
```

## Sanger Sequencing Workflow

For Sanger sequencing analysis, see the Sanger sequencing vignette:

```{r sanger}
# Load .ab1 files and create contigs
groups <- load.files(path = "path/to/ab1/files")

# Analyze sequences
analyze.sequences(
  groupdataframe = groups,
  contigName = "MyGene",
  GENETABLE = "~/BLAST_DB/16S/16S.fas"
)
```

## Visualization

### Radar Plots with Statistics

```{r radar-plot}
# Create radar plot with confidence intervals and p-values
data <- data.frame(
  group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 10),
  var1 = rnorm(20, mean = c(5, 7)),
  var2 = rnorm(20, mean = c(6, 8)),
  var3 = rnorm(20, mean = c(7, 6))
)

radar_with_p(
  data = data,
  group_col = "group",
  compare_groups = c("A", "B"),
  add_ci = TRUE
)
```

- Package development and deployment automation
- Utility functions for common R tasks
- GEO dataset processing tools
- Comprehensive 16S primer database and analysis
- Sanger sequencing workflow automation
- BLAST integration
- Advanced visualization tools

For specific workflows, please refer to the dedicated vignettes listed above.
